title: Getting Started
text: Example data original paper included package. ’ll use demonstration. data called lord_jcb. basic SuperPlot can generated following code:  generate SuperPlot Speed data, Treatment x-axis Replicate used group data. y-axis label set “Speed”. equivalent call long form :
code: library(SuperPlotR) superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)") superplot(   df = lord_jcb,   meas = "Speed",   cond = "Treatment",   repl = "Replicate",   ylab = "Speed (µm/min)" )

title: Getting Started
text: separate vignette describes customise sizing plot. , look major customisation options.

title: Getting Started
text: underlying data can rendered violins,  jittered scatter plot, default (shown first example page) uses sina jittered scatter plot density estimate.
code: superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",           ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", datadist = "violin") superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",           ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", datadist = "jitter")

title: Getting Started
text: colours points can changed. default Paul Tol’s bright palette ("tol_bright") can select : "tol_bright" "tol_vibrant" "tol_muted" "tol_light" Color Universal Design ("cud")  ’s possible supply palette vector colours (hex description format)
code: superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",           ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", pal = "cud") superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",           ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", pal = c("#ff0000", "blue", "green"))

title: Getting Started
text: mean replicate shown default. can show median instead

title: Getting Started
text: default SuperPlot include bars indicate mean ± error. can added using bars argument. Options : "mean_sd" = mean ± standard deviation "mean_sem" = mean ± standard error mean "mean_ci" = mean ± 95% confidence interval Note bars show mean ± error replicate means underlying data points.

title: Getting Started
text: default, data points circles. want use different shapes different conditions, can use shapes argument. Set TRUE use different shapes replicate.  ’d like link summary points, set linking = TRUE.  Linkages can made two groups. demonstrate use toy data:
code: superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",           ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", shapes = TRUE) superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",           ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", linking = TRUE) set.seed(123) example <- data.frame(meas = rep(rep(c(10, 9, 6, 6), each = 25), 4) + rnorm(400),                       cond = rep(rep(c("ctrl", "drug 1", "drug 2", "drug 3"), each = 25), 4),                       expt = rep(c("exp1","exp2","exp3","exp4"), each = 100)) superplot(example, "meas", "cond", "expt",           linking = TRUE)

title: Getting Started
text: SuperPlot can saved PDF PNG file using ggsave function ggplot2 package.
code: library(ggplot2) p <- superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",                ylab = "Speed (µm/min)") ggsave("superplot.pdf", p) #> Saving 6 x 4 in image

title: Getting Started
text: separate vignette describes customise SuperPlot . See vignette("advanced").

title: Advanced Usage
text: vignette, explore advanced features SuperPlotR. first, need deal simply scale plot looks good paper!

title: Advanced Usage
text: default setting use point sizes 2 data 3 summary points. font size 12. looks good RStudio viewer, well suited figure likely small.   look great viewer, look better figure.  preferable
code: library(SuperPlotR) # the default plot superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)") # the same plot but with custom sizing superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)",           size = c(0.8,1.5), fsize = 9) library(ggplot2) # the same plot but with custom sizing superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",                ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", size = c(0.8,1.5), fsize = 9) ggsave("plot.pdf", width = 88, height = 50, units = "mm") # final size library(ggplot2) # the same plot but with custom sizing superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",                ylab = "Speed (µm/min)") ggsave("plot.pdf", width = 88, height = 50, units = "mm") # final size

title: Advanced Usage
text: couple simple tweaks: x label can added, transparency points can altered like .  SuperPlotR returns ggplot object can customised like. example, theme can overridden like :  can also accept ggplot object using gg parameter, add SuperPlot (within reason!). example, might want plot something behind SuperPlot.
code: superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",           xlab = "Drug", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", alpha = c(0.3,1)) p <- superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)") p + theme_minimal() p <- ggplot() +   geom_hline(yintercept = 20, linetype = "dashed", col = "grey") superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", gg = p)

title: Advanced Usage
text: best done reordering levels factor input dataframe calling superplot.  also possible reorder Replicates using similar strategy. might want order colours shapes matches different order default. Another way achieve thing supply reordered colour palette superplot.
code: df <- lord_jcb df$Treatment <- factor(df$Treatment, levels = c("Drug", "Control")) superplot(df, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)")

title: Advanced Usage
text: made SuperPlot, might want know bit . example, might wonder replicate perhaps received warning replicates missing conditions. can set option info = TRUE call superplot get detailed information.  set, SuperPlot contain legend, otherwise, legend shown default. legend useful cases, colours shapes already shown plot. However, want see legend, can either set info = TRUE use append one output using + theme(legend.position = "right").
code: superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)",           info = TRUE) #> SuperPlot information #> ===================== #> Number of conditions: 2 #> Number of replicates: 3 #> Number of data points: 300 #> Number of summary points: 6 #> ===================== #> Colour palette: tol_bright #> Data distribution: sina #> Summary statistic: rep_mean #> No bars #> X-axis label: #> Y-axis label: Speed (µm/min) #> Point sizes: 2 (individual), 3 (summary) #> Alpha for points: 0.5 (individual), 0.7 (summary) #> Font size: 12 #> No statistics #> ===================== #> Colours for replicates: #4477AA, #CCBB44, #EE6677 #> Shapes for replicates: 21, 21, 21 #> ===================== #> Summary statistics: #> # A tibble: 6 × 6 #>   Treatment Replicate rep_mean rep_median sp_colour sp_shape #>   <chr>     <fct>        <dbl>      <dbl> <fct>     <fct>    #> 1 Control   1             41.5       41.7 #4477AA   21       #> 2 Control   2             32.6       34.4 #CCBB44   21       #> 3 Control   3             20.6       20.3 #EE6677   21       #> 4 Drug      1             29.6       30.1 #4477AA   21       #> 5 Drug      2             22.3       21.9 #CCBB44   21       #> 6 Drug      3             12.9       12.6 #EE6677   21

previous_headings: Advanced SuperPlots > Getting information about your SuperPlot
title: Advanced Usage
text: need retrieve summary data used create SuperPlot, can use get_sp_summary function. return data frame summary data used create SuperPlot.
code: summary_data <- get_sp_summary(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate") head(summary_data) #> # A tibble: 6 × 4 #>   Treatment Replicate rep_mean rep_median #>   <chr>         <int>    <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 Control           1     41.5       41.7 #> 2 Control           2     32.6       34.4 #> 3 Control           3     20.6       20.3 #> 4 Drug              1     29.6       30.1 #> 5 Drug              2     22.3       21.9 #> 6 Drug              3     12.9       12.6

previous_headings: Advanced SuperPlots > Getting information about your SuperPlot
title: Advanced Usage
text: want find representative datapoints condition, can use representative() function. handy data come set images ’d like show representative image figure. function returns data frame datapoints ranked closeness summary replicate condition (see ?representative information). also prints top ranked datapoint console. example, dataset label column, row number used label. label column, can specify using label parameter. label filename identifier identify datapoint came .
code: representative_data <- representative(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate") #> # A tibble: 6 × 6 #>   Treatment Replicate Speed rowno     diff  rank #>   <chr>     <chr>     <dbl> <int>    <dbl> <int> #> 1 Control   1          41.5     5 0.0524       1 #> 2 Control   2          32.9    98 0.220        1 #> 3 Control   3          20.7   124 0.0541       1 #> 4 Drug      1          29.4   178 0.217        1 #> 5 Drug      2          22.3   207 0.000237     1 #> 6 Drug      3          12.9   285 0.0113       1 head(representative_data) #> # A tibble: 6 × 6 #>   Treatment Replicate Speed rowno   diff  rank #>   <chr>     <chr>     <dbl> <int>  <dbl> <int> #> 1 Control   1          41.5     5 0.0524     1 #> 2 Control   1          41.4    13 0.0875     2 #> 3 Control   1          41.9     2 0.366      3 #> 4 Control   1          42.2    31 0.688      4 #> 5 Control   1          40.2    26 1.26       5 #> 6 Control   1          39.6    36 1.86       6 # Assuming lord_jcb has a column "FileName" with the labels example <- lord_jcb example$FileName <- paste0("Image_", seq_len(nrow(example)), ".tif") representative_data <- representative(example, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",                                       label = "FileName") #> # A tibble: 6 × 6 #>   Treatment Replicate Speed FileName          diff  rank #>   <chr>     <chr>     <dbl> <chr>            <dbl> <int> #> 1 Control   1          41.5 Image_5.tif   0.0524       1 #> 2 Control   2          32.9 Image_98.tif  0.220        1 #> 3 Control   3          20.7 Image_124.tif 0.0541       1 #> 4 Drug      1          29.4 Image_178.tif 0.217        1 #> 5 Drug      2          22.3 Image_207.tif 0.000237     1 #> 6 Drug      3          12.9 Image_285.tif 0.0113       1

title: Making non-SuperPlots - FlatPlots
text: SuperPlotR designed make SuperPlots, sometimes just want simple plot. vignette show make “FlatPlot” using SuperPlotR. contrast SuperPlots, emphasise experimental replicates, FlatPlots flat structure, replicates shown. can used look data single experiment, replicates individual data points.  Many arguments superplot(), replicate argument used.  control colour usually single colour, can hex code one lab’s publication colour palette.  also possible specify vector colours, used condition. extra colours ignored, valid inputs R colors, hex codes lab’s colour palette.  can request statistical testing SuperPlots, p-values calculated whole dataset, replicate.  example, increased size points, made slightly transparent, added error bars show mean 95% confidence interval.
code: library(SuperPlotR) flatplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", ylab = "Speed (um/min)") flatplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", ylab = "Speed (um/min)",          colour = "rl_green") flatplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", ylab = "Speed (um/min)",          colour = "rl_red", stats = TRUE) #> Performing t-test #>  #>  Welch Two Sample t-test #>  #> data:  x and y #> t = 8.7438, df = 279.51, p-value < 2.2e-16 #> alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>   7.738602 12.235350 #> sample estimates: #> mean of x mean of y  #>  31.58355  21.59657 flatplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", ylab = "Speed (um/min)",          colour = c("rl_red", "rl_blue", "rl_green")) flatplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", ylab = "Speed (um/min)",          colour = "rl_red", size = 4, alpha = 0.25,          bars = "mean_ci")

title: Limitations to SuperPlotR
text: limitations SuperPlotR. vignette covers offers solutions possible.

title: Limitations to SuperPlotR
text: Facetting partially supported. simple scenario facetting replicate, can :  another variable wished facet , facetting variable possible, limitation: summary points remain replicate summary therefore facet. may want.  Solution: best way achieve “facetting” currently (correct summary points) make SuperPlot variable, .e. filtering data frame B, combine using patchwork similar package.
code: library(SuperPlotR) library(ggplot2) p <- superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",                ylab = "Speed (µm/min)") p + facet_wrap(~Replicate) df <- cbind(lord_jcb, other = rep(c("A", "B"), 150)) p <- superplot(df, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)") p + facet_wrap(~other)

title: Limitations to SuperPlotR
text: dataset conditions replicates numeric, SuperPlotR converts character plotting. intended behaviour SuperPlot. Currently, data Conditions numeric, example time points, unevenly spaced, e.g. 0, 1, 3, 9 hours; appear evenly spaced x-axis. limitation current implementation. Raise issue like changed.

title: Limitations to SuperPlotR
text: Adding p-values stars SuperPlot currently supported due number different ways users may wish add . However, possible add manually SuperPlot object generated. SuperPlotR statistical testing (simple way) turned default. can turn setting stats = TRUE call superplot(). Four types statistical tests available: t-test, Wilcoxon rank sum test, ANOVA Kruskal-Wallis test. Select options setting stats_test one following: "para_unpaired" (default), "para_paired", "nonpara_unpaired" "nonpara_paired". number conditions two, options result : "para_unpaired": t-test "para_paired": paired t-test "nonpara_unpaired": Wilcoxon rank sum test .k.Mann-Whitney U test "nonpara_paired": Wilcoxon signed rank test number conditions greater two, options result : "para_unpaired": ANOVA followed Tukey’s HSD test "para_paired": Repeated measures ANOVA "nonpara_unpaired": Kruskal-Wallis test "nonpara_paired": direction perform Friedman test Returning example data, Lord et al. paper perform paired t-test data. can SuperPlotR setting stats = TRUE stats_test "para_paired". example, generate test data four treatments.
code: p <- superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", stats = TRUE) #> Performing t-test #>  #>  Welch Two Sample t-test #>  #> data:  x and y #> t = 1.2907, df = 3.8128, p-value = 0.2695 #> alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>  -11.91888  31.89283 #> sample estimates: #> mean of x mean of y  #>  31.58355  21.59657 p <- superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", stats = TRUE,                stats_test = "para_paired") #> Performing t-test #>  #>  Paired t-test #>  #> data:  x and y #> t = 8.1741, df = 2, p-value = 0.01464 #> alternative hypothesis: true mean difference is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>   4.730053 15.243899 #> sample estimates: #> mean difference  #>        9.986976 set.seed(123) example <- data.frame(meas = rep(rep(c(10, 9, 6, 6), each = 25), 4) + rnorm(400),                       cond = rep(rep(c("ctrl", "drug 1", "drug 2", "drug 3"), each = 25), 4),                       expt = rep(c("exp1","exp2","exp3","exp4"), each = 100)) superplot(example, "meas", "cond", "expt", linking = TRUE,           stats_test = "para_unpaired")

title: Making non-SuperPlots - PiePlots
text: convenience, SuperPlotR also provides function make pie charts. Called pieplot(), takes vector values vector colours, returns pie chart using ggplot2. can also take second vector values create pie chart two layers.   cols argument character vector colours, can hex codes one lab’s publication colour palette. function convert colours format ggplot2 can use.  Note values second pie chart layer first layer. function automatically scale second layer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Royle S (2025). SuperPlotR: Making SuperPlots R. R package version 0.0.8, https://github.com/quantixed/SuperPlotR.
code: @Manual{,   title = {SuperPlotR: Making SuperPlots in R},   author = {Stephen J Royle},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.8},   url = {https://github.com/quantixed/SuperPlotR}, }

title: Making SuperPlots in R
text: goal SuperPlotR allow user easily generate SuperPlots R. SuperPlots way visualise data way emphasises experimental reproducibility. can read SuperPlots original paper: Lord, S.J., Velle, K.B., Mullins, R.D. & Fritz-Laylin, L.K. (2020) SuperPlots: Communicating reproducibility variability cell biology. J. Cell Biol. 219(6):e202001064

title: Making SuperPlots in R
text: can install development version SuperPlotR GitHub :

title: Making SuperPlots in R
text: simple example use SuperPlotR shown :  data used example included package original paper. generate SuperPlot, need data frame least three columns. columns : variable measured experiment, experimental condition, experimental repeat measurment comes . superplot function takes data frame, names three columns, customisable additional arguments. See vignette("SuperPlotR") examples, vignette("advanced") advanced usage.

title: Making SuperPlots in R
text: SuperPlot package IGOR Pro available popular web-based app generating SuperPlots, developed Joachim Goedhart available

what: Add Mean ± Error Bars to a SuperPlot — add_sp_bars
title: Add Mean ± Error Bars to a SuperPlot — add_sp_bars
Add Mean ± Error Bars to a SuperPlot — add_sp_bars
Add Mean ± Error Bars to a SuperPlot — add_sp_bars
text: p ggplot object bars character string, one "mean_sd", "mean_sem", "mean_ci" df data frame summary data (supplied superplot()) cond character string condition column rep_summary character string replicate summary column

title: Add Mean ± Error Bars to a SuperPlot — add_sp_bars
Make a FlatPlot — flatplot
code: flatplot(   df,   meas,   cond,   colour = "#000000",   xlab = "",   ylab = "Measurement",   datadist = "sina",   size = 2,   alpha = 0.5,   bars = "mean_sd",   fsize = 12,   gg = NULL,   stats = FALSE,   stats_test = "para_unpaired" )

title: Make a FlatPlot — flatplot
text: df data frame least three columns: meas, cond, repl meas character name column measurement (e.g. intensity) cond character name column condition (e.g. Control, WT) colour string colour palette use, select ("rl_green", "rl_red", "rl_blue", "rl_purple", "rl_orange", "rl_magenta", hex colour, default black) xlab string x label (default empty) ylab string y label (default "Measurement") datadist string data distribution use, select ("sina" default, "jitter") size numeric size data points (default 2) alpha numeric vector alpha range data summary points (default c(0.5, 0.7)) bars string type error bars add, select ("none", "mean_sd" (default), "mean_sem", "mean_ci") fsize numeric font size text (default 12) gg ggplot object add (default NULL) stats logical whether add statistical tests (default FALSE) stats_test string statistical test use, select ("para_unpaired", "para_paired", "nonpara_unpaired", "nonpara_paired")

title: FlatPlot Colour Selection (Single Color) — get_fp_colour
text: key character name, can "rl_green", "rl_red", "rl_blue", "rl_yellow", "rl_purple", "rl_orange", "rl_magenta", hex colour

title: FlatPlot Colour Selection (Multiple Colors) — get_fp_colours
text: keys character vector color names/codes, can "rl_green", "rl_red", "rl_blue", "rl_yellow", "rl_purple", "rl_orange", "rl_magenta", hex colours, valid R color names

title: SuperPlot Colour Palette Selection — get_sp_colours
text: n integer number colours return scheme character name, colour scheme use Choose one four palettes Paul Tol ("tol_bright", "tol_vibrant", "tol_muted", "tol_light"), Color Universal Design ("cud"). vector colours, e.g. c("#FF0000", "green", "#0000FF").

title: Information about a SuperPlot — get_sp_info
text: function prints information SuperPlot, runs internally superplot()

title: Information about a SuperPlot — get_sp_info
code: get_sp_info(   df,   meas,   cond,   repl,   pal,   xlab,   ylab,   datadist,   size,   alpha,   bars,   linking,   rep_summary,   shapes,   fsize,   gg,   stats,   stats_test,   ... )

title: Information about a SuperPlot — get_sp_info
text: df data frame least three columns: meas, cond, repl meas character name column measurement (e.g. intensity) cond character name column condition (e.g. Control, WT) repl character name column replicate (e.g. unique experiment identifiers) pal argument passed pal xlab argument passed xlab ylab argument passed ylab datadist argument passed datadist size argument passed size alpha argument passed alpha bars argument passed bars linking argument passed linking rep_summary argument passed rep_summary shapes argument passed shapes fsize argument passed fsize gg argument passed gg stats argument passed stats stats_test argument passed stats_test ... additional arguments

text: n number shapes return shape_logical logical whether use different shapes replicates. Default FALSE, results circle used. TRUE means selection shapes used, data summary points replicate . Four shapes possible, n greater 4, shapes repeat (different colors).

text: df data frame containing data rep_summary summary statistic use testing cond column name condition repl column name replicate ncond number unique values cond nrepl number unique values repl stats_test string statistical test use, select ("para_unpaired", "para_paired", "nonpara_unpaired", "nonpara_paired")

title: Get statistical test results for the plotted data — get_sp_stats

what: Get summary statistics for SuperPlot data — get_sp_summary
title: Get summary statistics for SuperPlot data — get_sp_summary
text: function calculates summary statistics (mean median) combination condition replicate SuperPlot dataset.

title: Get summary statistics for SuperPlot data — get_sp_summary
Get summary statistics for SuperPlot data — get_sp_summary
text: df data frame containing experimental data meas Character string specifying name column containing measurements/values summarize (e.g., "intensity", "speed") cond Character string specifying name column containing experimental conditions (e.g., "Treatment", "Genotype") repl Character string specifying name column containing replicate identifiers (e.g., "Replicate", "Experiment") ... Additional arguments (ignored)

title: Get summary statistics for SuperPlot data — get_sp_summary
text: data frame columns condition, replicate, rep_mean (mean measurements), rep_median (median measurements)

title: Get summary statistics for SuperPlot data — get_sp_summary
text: useful get teh summary data computing stats making plots. function needs 4 parameters, anything else ignored. means can simply exchange get_sp_summary() superplot() call get correct data frame work .

title: Get summary statistics for SuperPlot data — get_sp_summary
code: # Using the built-in dataset get_sp_summary(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate") #> # A tibble: 6 × 4 #>   Treatment Replicate rep_mean rep_median #>   <chr>         <int>    <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 Control           1     41.5       41.7 #> 2 Control           2     32.6       34.4 #> 3 Control           3     20.6       20.3 #> 4 Drug              1     29.6       30.1 #> 5 Drug              2     22.3       21.9 #> 6 Drug              3     12.9       12.6

what: Report the representative datapoints in a SuperPlot — representative
title: Report the representative datapoints in a SuperPlot — representative
text: function finds representative datapoints condition replicate SuperPlot dataset. calculates mean median replicates (conditions), ranks individual measurements difference summary statistic. function returns data frame representative datapoints treatment replicate, along rank difference summary statistic.

title: Report the representative datapoints in a SuperPlot — representative
code: representative(   df,   meas,   cond,   repl,   label = "",   bars = "",   rep_summary = "rep_mean",   outlier = FALSE )

title: Report the representative datapoints in a SuperPlot — representative
text: df data frame least three columns: meas, cond, repl meas character name column measurement (e.g. intensity) cond character name column condition (e.g. Control, WT) repl character name column replicate (e.g. unique experiment identifiers) label character name column labels measurements (e.g. file names), optional. bars string specify summary stats replicate sumaries, select ("none" default, "mean_sd", "mean_sem", "mean_ci"). Sepcifying overrides rep_summary argument rep_summary string summary statistic use replicates, select ("rep_mean" default, "rep_median") outlier logical, TRUE ranking reversed find extreme datapoint treatment replicate, default FALSE.

title: Report the representative datapoints in a SuperPlot — representative
text: data frame representative datapoints treatment replicate, rank difference summary statistic.

title: Report the representative datapoints in a SuperPlot — representative
text: top ranked datapoint treatment replicate printed console. useful identifying representative datapoint condition, can used showing figure. label column can specified identify datapoint (file name identifier). label specified, row number used instead.

title: Report the representative datapoints in a SuperPlot — representative
code: representative(lord_jcb,   "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate") #> # A tibble: 6 × 6 #>   Treatment Replicate Speed rowno     diff  rank #>   <chr>     <chr>     <dbl> <int>    <dbl> <int> #> 1 Control   1          41.5     5 0.0524       1 #> 2 Control   2          32.9    98 0.220        1 #> 3 Control   3          20.7   124 0.0541       1 #> 4 Drug      1          29.4   178 0.217        1 #> 5 Drug      2          22.3   207 0.000237     1 #> 6 Drug      3          12.9   285 0.0113       1 #> # A tibble: 300 × 6 #>    Treatment Replicate Speed rowno   diff  rank #>    <chr>     <chr>     <dbl> <int>  <dbl> <int> #>  1 Control   1          41.5     5 0.0524     1 #>  2 Control   1          41.4    13 0.0875     2 #>  3 Control   1          41.9     2 0.366      3 #>  4 Control   1          42.2    31 0.688      4 #>  5 Control   1          40.2    26 1.26       5 #>  6 Control   1          39.6    36 1.86       6 #>  7 Control   1          39.5    37 1.97       7 #>  8 Control   1          43.7     1 2.20       8 #>  9 Control   1          39.2    27 2.24       9 #> 10 Control   1          43.8    17 2.27      10 #> # ℹ 290 more rows

title: Make a SuperPlot — superplot
code: superplot(   df,   meas,   cond,   repl,   pal = "tol_bright",   xlab = "",   ylab = "Measurement",   datadist = "sina",   size = c(2, 3),   alpha = c(0.5, 0.7),   bars = "",   linking = FALSE,   rep_summary = "rep_mean",   shapes = FALSE,   fsize = 12,   gg = NULL,   stats = FALSE,   stats_test = "para_unpaired",   info = FALSE )

title: Make a SuperPlot — superplot
text: df data frame least three columns: meas, cond, repl meas character name column measurement (e.g. intensity) cond character name column condition (e.g. Control, WT) repl character name column replicate (e.g. unique experiment identifiers) pal name colour palette use (default "tol_bright") xlab string x label (default empty) ylab string y label (default "Measurement") datadist string data distribution use, select ("sina" default, "jitter", "violin") size numeric vector size range data summary points (default c(2, 3)) alpha numeric vector alpha range data summary points (default c(0.5, 0.7)) bars string type error bars add, select ("none" default, "mean_sd", "mean_sem", "mean_ci") linking logical whether link summary points conditions (default FALSE) rep_summary string summary statistic use replicates, select ("rep_mean" default, "rep_median") shapes logical whether use different shapes replicates fsize numeric font size text (default 12) gg ggplot object add (default NULL) stats logical whether add statistical tests (default FALSE) stats_test string statistical test use, select ("para_unpaired", "para_paired", "nonpara_unpaired", "nonpara_paired") info logical whether print information plot (default FALSE)

title: SuperPlotR (development version)
